subsc: Central government administration,Tertiary education,Secondary education,General education sector

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            modest, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory,. The lessons learned indicate that conflict
            reverses the effects of development, imposes large economic
            and welfare costs on society, and hampers ongoing
            development activities in their implementation. A government
            emerging from conflict is likely to have a weak
            institutional and civil service capacity. Formal education
            at higher levels requires formal qualifications and
            credentials. An implementing partner abroad is key to
            effective management of funds, links with learning
            institutions, and follow-up of students abroad. Capacity
            development issues are complex phenomena relating to human,
            organizational and institutional change. The project used a
            cost-quality principle that has proven an important factor
            in achieving the outputs of the project. The project also
            used a cost-effectiveness principle, and the project has
            been much more cost-effective than originally anticipated,
            with US$20 million being re-allocated towards the emergency
            efforts, the project achieved nevertheless larger outputs in
            terms of Public Sector Employees (PSE's) trained and in
            terms of experts recruited.
